catch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to get hold of and stop an object such as a ball that is moving through the air
catch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Stephen leapt up and caught the ball in one hand.
‘Pass me that pen, would you?’ ‘Here you are. Catch!’
The kids were throwing and catching a Frisbee down on the beach.
catch.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to suddenly take hold of someone or something with your hand
catch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He caught her elbow to steady her.
Miss Perry caught hold of my sleeve and pulled me back.
catch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to stop someone after you have been chasing them and not let them get away
catch.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: ‘You can’t catch me!’ she yelled, running away.
catch.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to find a criminal or enemy and stop them from escaping
catch.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: State police have launched a massive operation to catch the murderer.
If you go back to the city, you’re bound to get caught.
catch.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to see someone doing something that they did not want you to know they were doing
catch.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: He was caught red-handed (=as he was doing something wrong) taking money from the cash register.
The gang was caught in the act of unloading the cigarettes.
catch somebody in the act (of doing something)
I caught him reading my private letters.
Gemma turned around and caught the stranger looking at her intently.
We knew he’d been cheating, but we’d never caught him at it before.
catch.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Anton caught malaria in Mali, and nearly died.
Many young people are still ignorant about how HIV is caught.
Don’t stand out in the rain. You’ll catch your death.
Typhoid and cholera are often caught from contaminated water supplies.
I caught chicken pox off my friend at school.
catch.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to trap an animal or fish by using a trap, net, or hook, or by hunting it
catch.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Early settlers caught rabbits and squirrels and even rats in order to survive.
catch.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to not be too late to do something, see something, talk to someone etc
catch.translation[0].definitions[7].note: catch the post British English (=post letters in time for them to be collected that day)
catch.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: I managed to catch her just as she was leaving.
I just caught the last few minutes of the documentary.
Tumours like these can be treated quite easily if they’re caught early enough.
catch.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if your hand, finger, clothing etc catches or is caught in something, it gets stuck in it accidentally
catch.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: His overalls caught in the engine.
Her microphone was forever getting caught on her clothes.
catch.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: to manage to hear a sound
catch.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: I caught the muffled thud of a car door slamming in the street.
catch.translation[0].definitions[10].def: to go somewhere in order to do or see something
catch.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: We could catch a movie (=go to a movie).
M Records caught his act and signed him immediately.
catch.translation[0].definitions[11].def: to show or describe the character or quality of something well in a picture, piece of writing etc
catch.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: a novel that catches the mood of post-war Britain
catch.translation[0].definitions[12].def: if something catches fire, it starts to burn accidentally
catch.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: Two farm workers died when a barn caught fire.
catch.translation[0].definitions[13].def: if a fire catches, it starts to burn
catch.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: For some reason the charcoal wasn’t catching.
catch.translation[0].definitions[14].def: to hit someone in or on a particular part of their body
catch.translation[0].definitions[14].exa: The punch caught him right in the face.
catch.translation[0].definitions[15].def: if a container catches liquid, it is in a position where the liquid falls into it
catch.translation[0].definitions[15].exa: Place the baking sheet under the muffin pan to catch the drips.
catch.translation[0].definitions[16].def: if the light catches something or if something catches the light, the light shines on it
catch.translation[0].definitions[16].exa: The sunlight caught her hair and turned it to gold.
catch.translation[0].definitions[17].def: if something catches the wind or the wind catches something, it blows on it
catch.translation[0].definitions[17].exa: Gary swung the sail round to catch the light wind.
catch.translation[0].definitions[18].def: to end a player’s innings in cricket by catching the ball that is hit off their bat before it touches the ground
catch.translation[0].definitions[19].def: to be the catcher in a game of baseball
catch.translation[0].note_box[0].section: catch
to stop someone who is trying to escape, especially by running after them and then holding them
He raced after her, but he couldn’t catch her.
The police caught the bank robbers after a car chase through the city.
arrest
if the police arrest someone, they take him or her to a police station because they think that person has done something illegal
Wayne was arrested for dangerous driving.
The police arrested him and charged him with murder.
apprehend
if the police apprehend someone they think has done something illegal, they catch him or her
The two men were later apprehended after they robbed another store.
The killers were never apprehended.
All of the kidnappers were apprehended and convicted.
capture
to catch an enemy or a criminal in order to keep them as a prisoner
The French king was captured by the English at the Battle of Poitiers in 1356.
The gunmen were finally captured after a shoot-out with the police.
take somebody prisoner
to catch someone, especially in a war, in order to keep them as a prisoner
350 soldiers were killed and another 300 taken prisoner.
Ellison was taken prisoner by the Germans during the retreat to Dunkirk.
trap
to make someone go to a place from which they cannot escape, especially by using your skill and intelligence
Police trapped the man inside a bar on the city’s southside.
corner
to force someone into a place from which they cannot escape
He was cornered outside the school by three gang members.
catch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: an act of catching a ball that has been thrown or hit
catch.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: This deal looks too good to be true – there must be a catch somewhere.
The catch is that you can’t enter the competition unless you’ve spent $100 in the store.
catch.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a hook or something similar for fastening a door or lid and keeping it shut
catch.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a quantity of fish that has been caught at one time
catch.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a simple game in which two or more people throw a ball to each other
catch.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Let’s go outside and play catch.
catch.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to be in a situation that is difficult to escape from
catch.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The government is caught in the middle of the dispute.
The yen was caught in a downward spiral.
catch.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to happen when you are not expecting it or not ready to deal with it
catch.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The sharp turn in share prices caught many investors by surprise.
Many oil companies were caught flatfooted when oil prices fell sharply with the start of the Gulf War.
catch.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: if a business catches a cold, it begins to have financial problems
catch.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: With the economic downturn, the recruitment industry will catch a cold.
